item.latestTitle: A bill to amend the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 respecting the scoring of preventive health savings.

bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 163, Number 105 (Tuesday, June 20, 2017)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BURGESS:H.R. 2953.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Section 8, Clause 1: The Congress shall have Power To layand collect Taxes, Duties, Imposts and Excises, to pay theDebts and provide for the common Defense and general Welfareof the United States; but all Duties, Imposts and Excisesshall be uniform throughout the United States.[Page H4994]
bill.title: To amend the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 respecting the scoring of preventive health savings.

item.title: To amend the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 respecting the scoring of preventive health savings.
To amend the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 respecting the scoring of preventive health savings.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Budget.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Budget.

item.name: Introduced in House
item.text: This bill amends the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 to require the Congressional Budget Office, upon receiving a request from Congress, to determine if legislation would reduce spending outside of the 10-year budget window through the use of preventive health and preventive health services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
